code: #' @title Correlation implies causation! #' #' @param df A `data.frame` with numeric columns #' #' @returns A `caugi` representing the causal graph that is totally true! correlation_implies_causation <- function(df) {   cg <- caugi::caugi(nodes = names(df))   cor_matrix <- cor(df)   # Add edges for correlations above 0.5   for (i in seq_len(ncol(cor_matrix))) {     for (j in 1:i) {       if (i != j && abs(cor_matrix[i, j]) > 0.5) {         from <- names(df)[j]         to <- names(df)[i]         cg <- caugi::add_edges(cg, from = from, edge = "-->", to = to) # add edge to caugi       }     }   }   return(cg) }

title: Visualizing Causal Graphs with caugi
text: caugi package provides four layout algorithms, optimized different use cases.

title: Visualizing Causal Graphs with caugi
text: Sugiyama layout (Sugiyama, Tagawa, Toda 1981) ideal directed acyclic graphs (DAGs). arranges nodes layers emphasize hierarchical structure causal flow top bottom, minimizing edge crossings.  Best : DAGs, causal models, hierarchical structures Limitations: works directed edges
code: # Create a more complex DAG dag <- caugi(   X1 %-->% M1 + M2,   X2 %-->% M2 + M3,   M1 %-->% Y,   M2 %-->% Y,   M3 %-->% Y,   class = "DAG" )  # Use Sugiyama layout explicitly plot(dag, layout = "sugiyama", main = "Sugiyama")

title: Visualizing Causal Graphs with caugi
text: Fruchterman-Reingold layout (Fruchterman Reingold 1991) uses physical simulation edges act springs nodes repel like charged particles. produces organic, symmetric layouts relatively uniform edge lengths.  Best : General-purpose visualization, graphs mixed edge types Advantages: Fast, works edge types, produces balanced layouts
code: # Create a graph with bidirected edges (ADMG) admg <- caugi(   A %-->% C,   B %-->% C,   A %<->% B, # Bidirected edge (latent confounder)   class = "ADMG" )  # Fruchterman-Reingold handles all edge types plot(admg, layout = "fruchterman-reingold", main = "Fruchterman-Reingold")

title: Visualizing Causal Graphs with caugi
text: Kamada-Kawai layout (Kamada Kawai 1989) minimizes ‚Äústress‚Äù making Euclidean distances plot proportional graph-theoretic distances. produces high-quality layouts better preserve global structure compared Fruchterman-Reingold.  Best : Publication-quality figures, accurate distance representation matters Advantages: Better global structure preservation
code: # Create an undirected graph ug <- caugi(   A %---% B,   B %---% C + D,   C %---% D,   class = "UG" )  plot(ug, layout = "kamada-kawai", main = "Kamada-Kawai")

title: Visualizing Causal Graphs with caugi
text: bipartite layout designed graphs clear two-group structure, treatment/outcome exposure/response relationships. arranges nodes two parallel lines (rows columns). ‚Äôs example bipartite causal graph treatments outcomes: Horizontal rows (treatments top, outcomes bottom)  Vertical columns (treatments left, outcomes right)  bipartite layout automatically detects nodes partition based incoming edges. Nodes incoming edges placed one group, nodes incoming edges placed . can also specify partition explicitly:  Best : Treatment-outcome structures, exposure-response models, bipartite causal relationships Advantages: Clear visual separation, emphasizes directed relationships groups
code: bipartite_graph <- caugi(   Treatment_A %-->% Outcome_1 + Outcome_2 + Outcome_3,   Treatment_B %-->% Outcome_1 + Outcome_2,   Treatment_C %-->% Outcome_2 + Outcome_3,   class = "DAG" ) plot(   bipartite_graph,   layout = "bipartite",   orientation = "rows" ) plot(   bipartite_graph,   layout = "bipartite",   orientation = "columns" ) partition <- c(TRUE, TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE, FALSE) plot(   bipartite_graph,   layout = caugi_layout_bipartite,   partition = partition,   orientation = "rows" )

title: Visualizing Causal Graphs with caugi
text: graphs two hierarchical levels, tiered layout places nodes multiple parallel tiers. ideal visualizing causal structures clear stages, exposures ‚Üí mediators ‚Üí outcomes. First, create simple three-tier causal graph: can define tiers using named list:  tiered layout supports three input formats: named lists, named numeric vectors, data.frames. Named lists intuitive format, already shown. can also use named numeric vector:  Finally, can use data.frame specify tiers directly.  Best : Multi-stage causal processes, mediation analysis, temporal sequences, hierarchical structures Advantages: Clear stage separation, flexible tier assignment, supports 2+ tiers, multiple input formats
code: cg_tiered <- caugi(   X1 %-->% M1 + M2,   X2 %-->% M1 + M2,   M1 %-->% Y,   M2 %-->% Y ) tiers <- list(   exposures = c("X1", "X2"),   mediators = c("M1", "M2"),   outcome = "Y" )  plot(cg_tiered, layout = "tiered", tiers = tiers, orientation = "rows") tiers_vector <- c(X1 = 1, X2 = 1, M1 = 2, M2 = 2, Y = 3) plot(cg_tiered, layout = "tiered", tiers = tiers_vector, orientation = "columns") tiers_df <- data.frame(   name = c("X1", "X2", "M1", "M2", "Y"),   tier = c(1, 1, 2, 2, 3) )  layout_df <- caugi_layout_tiered(cg_tiered, tiers_df, orientation = "rows")  plot(cg_tiered, layout = layout_df)

title: Compute Graph Layout ‚Äî caugi_layout
text: Sugiyama (Hierarchical Layout) Optimized directed acyclic graphs (DAGs). Places nodes layers emphasize hierarchical structure causal flow top bottom. Edges routed minimize crossings. Best visualizing clear cause-effect relationships. works directed edges. Fruchterman-Reingold (Spring-Electrical) Fast force-directed layout using spring-electrical model. Treats edges springs nodes electrically charged particles. Produces organic, symmetric layouts uniform edge lengths. Good general-purpose visualization works edge types. Results deterministic. Kamada-Kawai (Stress Minimization) High-quality force-directed layout minimizes "stress" making Euclidean distances proportional graph-theoretic distances. Better preserves global structure path lengths compared Fruchterman-Reingold. Ideal publication-quality visualizations accurate distance representation matters. Works edge types produces deterministic results.

code: cg <- caugi(   A %-->% B + C,   B %-->% D,   C %-->% D,   class = "DAG" )  # Default: auto-selects best layout layout <- caugi_layout(cg)  # Auto-selects tiered when tiers provided cg_tiered <- caugi(X1 %-->% M1, X2 %-->% M2, M1 %-->% Y, M2 %-->% Y) tiers <- list(c("X1", "X2"), c("M1", "M2"), "Y") layout_auto <- caugi_layout(cg_tiered, tiers = tiers) # Uses "tiered"  # Explicitly use hierarchical layout layout_sug <- caugi_layout(cg, method = "sugiyama")  # Use force-directed for organic appearance layout_fr <- caugi_layout(cg, method = "fruchterman-reingold")  # Use stress minimization for publication quality layout_kk <- caugi_layout(cg, method = "kamada-kawai")  # Bipartite layout with auto-detected partition cg_bp <- caugi(A %-->% X, A %-->% Y, B %-->% X, B %-->% Y) layout_bp_rows <- caugi_layout(   cg_bp,   method = "bipartite",   orientation = "rows" )  # Explicit partition partition <- c(TRUE, TRUE, FALSE, FALSE) layout_bp_cols <- caugi_layout(   cg_bp,   method = "bipartite",   partition = partition,   orientation = "columns" )  # Tiered layout with three tiers cg_tiered <- caugi(   X1 %-->% M1 + M2,   X2 %-->% M1 + M2,   M1 %-->% Y,   M2 %-->% Y ) tiers <- list(c("X1", "X2"), c("M1", "M2"), "Y") layout_tiered <- caugi_layout(   cg_tiered,   method = "tiered",   tiers = tiers,   orientation = "rows" )

title: caugi 1.0.0
text: Add support Ancestral Graphs (AGs), combine directed (-->), bidirected (<->), undirected (---) edges satisfying ancestral graph constraints. New functions: is_ag(), is_mag(). Add mode argument neighbors()/neighbours() filter neighbors edge direction type ("", "", "", "undirected", "bidirected", "partial"). structural query, semantic query! neighbors() now supports class = "UNKNOWN" graphs, including mode-based filtering. Add simulate_data() enables simulation DAGs using SEMs. Standard linear Gaussian SEMs defaults, importantly custom SEMs available. Add "AUTO" parameter class caugi objects. automatically picks graph class order DAG, UG, PDAG, ADMG, AG. Add Ancestral Graphs (AG) support directed, bidirected, undirected edges, plus new queries is_ag() is_mag() m-separation AGs. Add exogenize() function exogenizes variables graph type. Current implementation written R, simple might preferable Rust implementation. might changed later. Add latent_project() function latent projection DAGs ADMGs. Add native caugi serialization format saving loading graphs. New functions: write_caugi(), read_caugi(), caugi_serialize(), caugi_deserialize(). format versioned JSON schema captures graph structure, class, optional metadata (comments tags). Add plot() method visualizing graphs using various layout algorithms. plot rendered using grid graphics returns caugi_plot object can customized node_style, edge_style, label_style arguments. plot() method accepts layouts strings, functions, pre-computed data.frames. Add caugi_layout() function compute node coordinates graph visualization. Add dedicated layout functions: caugi_layout_sugiyama(), caugi_layout_fruchterman_reingold(), caugi_layout_kamada_kawai(), caugi_layout_bipartite(), caugi_layout_tiered(). function provides API specific algorithm. Add to_dot() write_dot() functions exporting caugi graphs DOT (graphviz) format. resulting object new S7 class, caugi_export, knit_print() method rendering DOT graphs R Markdown Quarto documents. Add GraphML Mermaid import/export support: to_graphml, write_graphml, read_graphml, to_mermaid, write_mermaid, read_mermaid Add plot composition operators creating multi-plot layouts: + | horizontal arrangement, / vertical stacking. Compositions can nested arbitrarily (e.g., (p1 + p2) / p3). Add caugi_options() function setting global defaults plot appearance, including composition spacing default styles nodes, edges, labels, titles. Add caugi_default_options() function query reset package default options. Add new vignette, ‚ÄúGraph Visualization caugi‚Äù, demonstrating new plotting capabilities customization options.
